title: Olympian’s PA apologises after video proves driver she accused did not endanger cyclist
text:
Bryony Evens has said sorry for getting it wrong (Pictures: Deadline)

Olympic cycling gold medallist Chris Boardman’s assistant has admitted she was wrong when she accused a coach driver of endangering a cyclist’s life.

Bryony Evens criticised driver Geoff Goodwin after she heard him beep at the woman outside Greater Manchester cycling and walking commissioner Mr Boardman’s office on September 6.

Ms Evens, who did not see the incident but heard Mr Goodwin beeping, wrote an email to his firm, GO Goodwins Coaches, headed: ‘Aggressive driving report.’

She claimed he needed to be retrained to drive safely and it was ‘his responsibility to follow the Highway Code and slow down or stop if he is not able to pass.’

But Mr Goodwin, 61, who owns the coach firm and was driving the Australian cricket team, obtained a video from his £12,000 360-degree camera system that proved the cyclist was at fault for attempting an overtake on the inside.

Chris Boardman’s assistant Bryony Evens has apologised (Picture: Deadline)

She thought the coach driver had endangered the cyclist’s life (Picture: Deadline)

When Ms Evens saw the video she issued a full apology to him and admitted ‘jumping to the wrong conclusion’.

She added: ‘I have offered a full apology to the Goodwin’s bus driver and I hope this will be accepted.

‘I am someone who is passionate about cycling and walking and in my professional life, I work to ensure that other cyclists and pedestrians are as safe as they can be when using our roads.

‘However, in this case, I clearly jumped to the wrong conclusion and made a mistake. It is clear that the company takes protecting other road users very seriously.’

Geoff Goodwin with his wife Suzanne in front of his coach (Picture: Deadline)

Olympic champion Chris Boardman Picture: Rex)

Mr Goodwin was not impressed with the apology and said: ‘I just think, what gives her the right to accuse me of this? It’s not about her getting it wrong, it’s about her making the story up without witnessing it.’

Mr Goodwin was driving the Australian cricket team through Manchester in his £500,000 coach when he had an altercation with the cyclist.

At the start of her career Ms Evens worked at a literary agency where she read the manuscript of JK Rowling’s first Harry Potter novel and claims to have discovered the writer.

Mr Boardman is a British former racing cyclist who won an individual pursuit gold medal at the 1992 Summer Olympics, broke the world hour record three times, and won three stages and wore the yellow jersey on three separate occasions at the Tour de France.

In 1992, he was awarded an MBE for services to cycling.

description: Olympic gold medallist Chris Boardman's personal assistant has admitted she was wrong when she accused a coach driver of endangering a cyclist’s life.
